Styrene is an important building block of the plastics industry being produced by ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. The commercial catalysts have the disadvantages of deactivation by potassium loss and coke deposition, and chromium toxicity. To overcome these drawbacks, a new catalyst was developed by investigating the effect of magnesium on the catalytic properties of hematite in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. Hematite was detected for all fresh catalysts and magnetite for the spent ones. Magnesium was found as magnesium ferrite and magnesium oxide, depending on the magnesium amount. Magnesium compounds affect the crystal sizes, the amount of defects and the reducibility of iron oxides, the predominance of each one depending on the composition of the solids. These effects caused important differences in activity, selectivity and stability of the catalysts. The catalyst with Mg/Fe = 0.09, consisting of aggregates of hematite, MgO and magnesium ferrite, showed the highest yield, being the most promising for commercial applications. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ethylbenzene dehydrogenation Styrene Hematite Magnesia Magnesium ferrite Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Styrene is one of the most important monomers, being a basic building block of the plastics industry worldwide. It is used in the manufacture of plastics, resins, and elastomers, including polystyrene and acrylonitrile-butadiene styrene (ABS). According to Styrene Global Market Report 2022, the global styrene market is expected to grow from $49.3 billion in 2021 to $52.28 billion in 2022 and to $62.81 billion in 2026. Most of the production of styrene is driven to polystyrene production. Polystyrene is used to manufacture ovens, microwaves, vacuum cleaners, and in the packaging industry. In the automobile industry, it is used in instrument panels, trim, energy-absorbing door panels, and sound-dampening foam [1]. Currently, most of the commercial production of styrene comes from the catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene, which accounts for around 90% of this monomer in the world [2]. The process suffers from high energy consumption, equilibrium-limited ethylbenzene conversion, and catalyst deactivation [2,3]. This well-established technology is more than eight decades old, having received much attention and improvements over the years [4–6]. Several non-conventional catalysts have been proposed, such as tin-decorated ceria catalyst [7], nanodiamond-based monolithic foam catalyst [8] and three dimensional SiC@C hybrid catalyst [9], among others. Other studies have focused on the use of different oxidants, like carbon dioxide [2,4,5,10–16] or nitrous oxide [9,17], instead of steam. The use of a circulating fluidized bed reactor has also been proposed [18] to decrease the steam-to-ethylbenzene ratio. However, these processes are still under research as there are some technological barriers to their commercialization. Under reaction conditions, other reactions occur simultaneously with ethylbenzene dehydrogenation (Eqs. 1 to 6) [3,5,19]·The main reaction (Eq. 1) is reversible, endothermic, and limited by equilibrium, depending on the partial pressure of the components and on the temperature [5]·Therefore, high temperatures and low partial pressures of ethylbenzene are required by the process, which is performed industrially at around 600 °C and 0·1 atm, achieving 50% and 60% conversion [5,20]·To provide heat to the reaction (6·3 × 106 kJ styrene ton−1), large amounts of steam (steam/ethylbenzene molar ratio in the range of 6–13:1) are fed to the reactor·The typical by-products are benzene (around 1%) and toluene (around 2%) formed by catalytic dealkylation and hydrodesalkylation of ethylbenzene, respectively [3,19]· (1) C 6 H 5 CH 2 CH 3 ⇄ C 6 H 5 CH = CH 2 + H 2 Δ H = 124.9 kJmol − 1 (2) C6H5CH2CH3→C6H6 + C2H4 ΔH = 101·7 kJ·mol−1 (3) C6H5CH2CH3→C6H5CH3 + CH4 ΔH = −64·5 kJ·mol−1 (4) C6H5CH2CH3→8 C + 5 H2 ΔH = −1·67 kJ·mol−1 (5) CH4 + H2O→CO + 3 H2 ΔH = 206·0 kJ·mol−1 (6) CO + H2O→CO2 + H2 ΔH = −41·2 kJ·mol−1 The conventional commercial catalysts for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation are based on hematite (α-Fe2O3), and contain chromium oxide and potassium oxide, which act as textural and structural promoters, respectively. Their use has several advantages, such as low cost and high resistance to poisoning. However, the active Fe3+ sites are unstable, the specific surface area of the catalyst is low, and it deactivates during commercial operations mainly because of migration and loss of potassium ions from the catalyst [3,20,21]. These drawbacks lead to reduced activity, stability, and mechanical strength [3,5,6,20]. In addition, the toxicity of chromium compounds makes the handling and disposal of the catalysts difficult. These drawbacks have driven the research to develop chromium and potassium-free catalysts with high and stable specific surface areas. A significant amount of work has been dedicated for replacing chromium oxide by alternative non-toxic dopants [18,22,26]. All these solids are made up of iron oxides modified with different metals, replacing chromium and/or potassium. The comparison of different metals (neodymium, aluminum, lanthanum, and zirconium), on the catalytic properties of hematite, for instance, showed that several dopants increase the catalytic activity per area (intrinsic activity) of hematite, except for aluminum that only improves the specific surface area of iron oxides. The catalyst containing neodymium showed the highest activity and selectivity, being the most promising for the production of styrene [26]. Another study [27] showed that zinc affects the properties of potassium-free iron oxide, acting as a structural promoter due to its ability to stabilize Fe3+ species. The zinc-containing catalyst was four times more active than that of pure iron oxide. However, the selectivity of the two catalysts was close to each other. Aluminum ferrite was more active and more resistant to deactivation by reduction of Fe3+ species (hematite) than those of aluminum-doped hematite [28]. However, it was less selective than doped hematite. Lanthanum-doped hematite has been extensively studied. Santos et al. [23–25], for instance, have studied the textural and catalytic properties of lanthanum-doped hematite prepared using several precipitants (ammonium and sodium hydroxide; sodium and potassium carbonate) by different methods. They found that the most promising route was the slow addition of metal nitrates and potassium carbonate to water. The use of sodium carbonate or sodium hydroxide, instead of ammonium hydroxide, resulted in bulkier particles with lower specific surface areas. In addition, sodium species were found to deposit on the surface of the catalysts, partially covering the iron active sites of iron, and decreasing the catalytic activity. On the contrary, ammonium hydroxide produced the most active and selective catalysts. Moreover, the most suitable iron molar to lanthanum molar ratio was 10. The effect of the precipitating agent on the properties of hematite catalysts was also investigated using aluminum instead of lanthanum. Ammonium hydroxide produced the most active and selective catalysts, followed by sodium carbonate. However, the most stable catalysts were prepared with carbonate or potassium hydroxide [22]. In this work, the effect of magnesium on the catalytic properties of hematite in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation was studied. It is expected that magnesium can improve the specific surface area and the electronic properties of iron oxide, replacing both chromium and potassium oxide. It is also expected that avoiding chromium oxide, an environmentally friendly catalyst will be produced. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared through the sol-gel method by simultaneously mixing iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3. 9 H2O), magnesium (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2. 6 H2O) and a concentrated ammonium hydroxide solution. For this, 250 mL of an iron nitrate solution (1 mol L−1) was mixed with 250 mL of a magnesium nitrate solution (0.01, 0.03, 0.06 or 0.09 mol L−1) and then simultaneously added with ammonium hydroxide solution (25% v/v) to water under stirring at room temperature. After the complete addition of the reactants (pH= 10.2), the system was kept under stirring for 30 min and then centrifuged (2000 rpm, 5 min). The gel obtained was rinsed with water and centrifuged until no nitrate ions were detected in the supernatant anymore. The gel was dried in an oven at 120 ºC, for 12 h, ground and sieved (100 mesh). The solid was then heated (25 °C min−1) under nitrogen flow (100 mL min−1) up to 600 ºC and kept at this temperature for 2 h. The same experimental procedure was followed to prepare pure iron oxide and pure magnesium oxide, to be used as references. Samples were named F for pure iron oxide, M for pure magnesium oxide and M01, M03, M06 and M09 for magnesium and iron-containing solids, where the numbers indicate the amount of magnesium in solids (Mg/Fe molar ratio). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction performed at room temperature in a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a Cu-Kα tube (λ = 0.15418 nm) at 40 kV generator voltage, tube current of 25 mA, in the 2θ range from 10º to 80º with an angle step of 0.01º and scanning speed of 0.00416º. The crystalline phases were identified using the X-Pert High Score software by ICDD PDF2 crystallography data bank and the Rietveld refinement were done using the program package GSAS and the starting structural models used were based on information given in the ICSD database [29]. The structural refinement was carried out using the modified Thompson–Cox–Hasting pseudo-Voigt profile function that considers the particle size and microstrain broadening description [30]. Thus, the mean crystallite sizes (L) and microstrain percent (σ) were obtained by the formalism shown in [31], where instrumental broadening was removed by LaB6 standard powder sample. For all patterns were refined the background parameters (using a shifted Chebyshev function type with four terms), cell parameters, sample position shift, phase fractions, peak shape parameters. Moreover, isotropic atomic dislocation (Uiso) parameters were refined for all the atoms. The refinement data is showed in the Tables S1 and S2. Mössbauer spectra for fresh and spent catalysts were obtained at 25 °C and − 243 °C in a spectrometer with 512 channels, constant acceleration, and geometry of transmission. A 57Co source in Rh matrix of nominally 50 mCi was used. The velocity calibration was performed against a 12 µm-thick α-Fe foil. All isomer shifts (δ) mentioned in this paper were referred to this standard. For each component of the spectra, Lorentzians lines of the same width were used. The spectra were folded to minimize geometric effects and were fitted using a commercial software named Recoil [32]. The specific surface areas (BET method) for the fresh and spent catalysts were obtained by nitrogen adsorption at − 196 °C, using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Before analysis, the sample (150 mg) was heated up to 200 ºC under a vacuum in order to remove volatile compounds and moisture from the solids. The scanning electron microscopy experiments were performed on FESEM-EDS Gemini 360 ZEISS equipment using the samples as powder. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out in a Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 device. Before analyses, the sample (80 mg) was heated up to 160 ºC at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen flow (60 mL min−1), in order to remove water and then cooled to room temperature. During analyses, the samples were heated from 30° to 1000°C, using a 5% H2/N2 mixture. The uncertainty was estimated as 2% using three runs. The XPS spectra were obtained in a VG Scientific spectrometer, Escalab model 220i-XL, using a source of X-rays, Mg Kα (1253 eV) anode, 4000 W power and hemispherical electron analyzer. The Al 2p peak (BE = 74.5 eV) was chosen as an internal reference. This reference was in all cases in good agreement with the BE of the C 1 s peak, arising from contamination, at 284.6 eV. This reference gives an accuracy of + 0.1 eV. Elemental analysis of the samples was performed dissolving the solids on concentrated hydrochloric acid and keeping the solution under reflux for 1 h. After cooling and dilution, the samples were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) on a model 5110 Agilent equipment. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalysts were evaluated in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation using 300 mg of powder in a tubular fixed bed microreactor under isothermal conditions (530 °C) and at atmospheric pressure. The contact time was adjusted to get an ethylbenzene conversion of 10% over an iron and chromium oxide commercial catalyst. The runs were repeated three times for each catalyst and the average values were considered. A divergence of around 7% was obtained. for conversion and 5% for selectivity. The stainless-steel reactor containing the catalyst was heated under nitrogen flow (60 mL min−1) up to the reaction temperature. Then, nitrogen was replaced by the reaction mixture, coming from a chamber where ethylbenzene diluted in nitrogen was mixed with steam (steam/ ethylbenzene molar ratio = 10) produced in a saturator. The gaseous effluent was collected in a condenser and the organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography using a Beckman GC-35 instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction The X-ray diffractograms for the catalysts before and after ethylbenzene dehydrogenation are shown in Fig. 1, with the best fits from Rietveld refinements (Tables S1 and S2). The single hematite (α-Fe2O3) phase (trigonal, space group R −3 c: ICSD #40142) was observed in F (pure iron oxide) and M01 samples. As expected, hematite was the majority phase observed for all sequential samples with Mg addition. Additionally, MgFe2O4 (cubic, space group F d −3 m: ICSD #76176) phase was observed for all solids, except for M01 sample. A small contribution of MgO phase (cubic, F m −3 m: ICSD #64928) was observed only for M03 (0.8 wt%) and M09 (1.3 wt%) samples. The MgO phase quantification was obtained adjusting the majority phases first and adding its phase only after reaching refinement stability. Thus, the values obtained for the major phases were kept fixed and only the parameters of the MgO phase were adjusted, thus better values of Chi square (χ2) and R-factor (R) were obtained, which indicates the existence of the MgO phase, even if in a very low percentage. The detected phases are shown in Table 1. The percentages of magnesium-containing phases increased with magnesium amount in the samples, and the amount of magnesium ferrite is superior to magnesium oxide for all cases. It means that during the sample preparation, small amounts of iron hydroxide react with magnesium hydroxide to produce magnesium ferrite during calcination. Simultaneously, even smaller amounts of magnesium hydroxide decompose to produce magnesium oxide. During ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, magnesium oxide disappeared, and the amount of magnesium ferrite increased (Fig. 1b and Table 1), meaning that magnesium ferrite is the most favorable magnesium-containing phase under reaction medium. On the other hand, hematite changed to magnetite, Fe3O4 (cubic, space group F d −3 m: ICSD #50567), the majority phase in the spent catalysts. Moreover, the MgFe2O4 (ICSD #76176) phase was observed with increase of the wt% to increasing the Mg ratio from 2.3, 5.7 and 8.6. For M01 sample before and after reaction, the presence of magnesium-containing phases could not be detected by X-ray diffraction, probably because of their low amounts, below the detection limit (lower than 0.5%, depending on the analysis conditions and on the sample). Moreover, the mean crystallite sizes to the hematite phase decrease from 98.3 nm for F sample to around 53 nm for M01 and M03 samples. Increasing the Mg ratio up to 6% (M06 sample) the was observed an increase of D close to 106 nm, however, was obtained L ∼ 50 nm for M09 sample. Additionally, the microstrain had an increasing behavior for higher percentages of Mg, which is consistent with greater structural defects due to the coexistence/competition of two or more crystalline phases in the samples. The most completely structural information and fittings data were showed in the Table S1. Additionally, small variation with a downward trend was observed to the mean crystallite sizes for magnetite, remaining slightly above 80 nm. However, a clear increasing trend, ranging from 15.5 nm, 21.7 nm and 23.4 nm, was observed for the average crystallite size of the MgFe2O4 phase from M03, M06 and M09, respectively. Finally, the microstrains increase/decrease for increasing the Mg ratio for the Fe3O4/MgFe2O4 phases, suggesting that the increase in the minority (MgFe2O4) phase implies a greater density of structural defects in the majority phase (Fe3O4). 3.2 Mössbauer spectroscopy The Mössbauer spectra of the fresh catalysts obtained at 25 °C are shown in Fig. 2a and the hyperfine parameters in Table S3. For pure iron oxide (F) and the samples with low magnesium contents (M01 and M03) the spectra were fitted with a single sextet whose hyperfine parameters correspond to hematite [33] . However, some differences were detected in these samples. When adding magnesium, a decrease in the hyperfine magnetic field occurs in the order: F> M01 > M03. Alongside, an increase in the width of the distribution of hyperfine magnetic fields is observed. A priori, these effects could be attributed to the following causes: (i) isomorphic substitution of Fe3+ ions in hematite octahedral sites by Mg2+ ions; (ii) introduction of Mg2+ ions in empty tetrahedral sites of hematite or (iii) formation of a segregated phase that would grow at the grain edges of the hematite particle, producing a decrease in its crystal size and an increase in the width of their size distribution. A possible cause of the magnetic hyperfine field decreasing is discussed below. The Mössbauer spectra of M06 and M09 catalysts obtained at room temperature showed three sextets (Fig. 2a). The sextet with the highest intensity has hyperfine parameters of hematite [33]. The other two sextets have hyperfine parameters assigned to Fe3+ ions located at octahedral (site B) and tetrahedral (site A) sites of magnesium ferrite, MgFe2O4 [34]. The signals from the two sites are superimposed and the values of the areas are low and then the parameters may present high errors. Because of this, in the case of the A-site which has the lowest percentage, it was necessary to fix the hyperfine parameter. Despite these difficulties, the production of magnesium ferrite can be confirmed. When going from M03 to the M06 sample, the hyperfine field of hematite undergoes a strong increase (51.09 + 0.01 T of M03 vs 51.62+0.08 T of M06). However, from the M06 to M09 sample, the hyperfine magnetic field decreases again (51.62 + 0.08 T from M06 vs 51.03 + 0.01 T from M09). In order to distinguish between the different causes that can lead to this behavior in the hyperfine magnetic field of hematite, Mössbauer spectra at − 243 °C were also registered. The Mössbauer spectra of the catalysts obtained at − 243 °C are shown in Figure S1 and the hyperfine parameters are shown in Table S4. The spectra of F, M01 and M03 catalysts were fitted with one sextet whose hyperfine parameters correspond to hematite, in agreement with the results at room temperature. On the other hand, the Mössbauer spectra of M06 and M09 samples obtained at − 243 °C were fitted with three sextets. The most intense sextet corresponds to hematite and the other two sextets were assigned to Fe3+ ions located at octahedral (B sites) and tetrahedral (A sites) of magnesium ferrite, MgFe2O4 [34] in the same way that at room temperature. Bulk hematite has a magnetic transition from a weakly ferromagnetic phase to an antiferromagnetic phase at − 10 °C named Morin transition. When this transition happens, the quadrupole shift, 2ε, shows an important change (from ≅ −0.21 mm.s−1 to ≅ +0.37 mm.s−1). Comparing the values of 2ε obtained at 25 and − 243 °C all samples go through the Morin transition. From this result two conclusions can be obtained: (1) the hematite crystal size is larger than 20 nm in all catalysts because below this size this transition is suppressed [31] and. (2) magnesium ions would not replace Fe3+ ions in hematite lattice neither would occupy the empty tetrahedral sites of hematite. Several authors [35–37] have found that hematite lattice doped with minor quantities of alkaline earth ions inhibit the Morin transition. Therefore, we can infer that in M01 and M03 samples, MgO and/or MgFe2O4 would be segregated (both detected for M03 sample by X-ray diffraction) co-existing with α-Fe2O3. The presence of magnesium ferrite could not be detected by Mössbauer spectroscopy probably because the detection limit of this technique. However, when certain magnesium loading is surpassed (between 0.03 and 0.06 molar ratio) MgFe2O4 is detected. This phase consumes magnesium ions and again inhibits the Morin transition. The reminiscent magnesium forms magnesium oxide, as detected by X-ray diffraction. The phases found by Mössbauer spectroscopy are shown in Table 2. From these results, other effects must be considered in order to explain the hyperfine magnetic fields changes when magnesium loading is increased. Previously it has been demonstrated that the hyperfine magnetic field is sensitive to modifications of the crystal size in iron oxides [34]. Mørup and Topsøe developed the collective magnetic excitations model which can be used to estimate the crystal sizes from the decreasing of the hyperfine magnetic field in comparison with the bulk value [38]. Using a basal magnetic anisotropy constant, KBU, of 1.3 × 103 J m−3 suitable for hematite particles bigger than 20 nm [39], one can estimate the size of hematite crystals using Eq. (7), where Hobs is the hyperfine magnetic field of hematite in the sample; Hbulk is the hyperfine magnetic field of bulk hematite kB is the Boltzmann constant; T is the absolute temperature at which the spectrum was obtained and V is the crystal volume. (7) H obs = H bulk 1 − k B T 2 K BU V The results obtained are shown in Table 2. In agreement with the experimental observation that all samples undergone the Morin transition, all particle sizes calculated are bigger than 20 nm (Table 2). These results agree with the average crystallite size calculated by Rietveld refinement from X-ray diffraction results (Table 1). As found by these results, magnesium ions do not replace Fe3+ ions in hematite lattice neither occupy the empty tetrahedral sites of hematite but rather form other phases. This founding is in accordance with X-ray diffraction, as shown in Table 1. For hematite crystals, magnesium decreased the crystal sizes up to Mg/Fe= 0.03 and also to M09 sample, which can be related to magnesium compounds on the surface, as shown by the following results of XPS. On the other hand, for the other phases, the crystal sizes increased with magnesium amount. The smallest particle size was detected for MgO phase indicating the highest dispersion of these particles. Because of the lowest magnesium loading the smallest particles is expected for M01 sample, make the detection more difficult. The Mössbauer spectra for the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 2b. Under reaction conditions α-Fe2O3 phase was reduced to Fe3O4. In Table S5 are reported the hyperfine parameters obtained using the fitting procedure, previously described. There is an excellent agreement between these values and that reported in bibliography for this species [40,41]. For the M06 and M09 samples, when Fe3O4 is produced under reaction conditions, the hyperfine parameters of Fe3+ ions situated in A sites of Fe3O4 are indistinguishable from that of Fe3+ ions located in B sites of MgFe2O4. Therefore, only three sextets were utilized to fit the Mössbauer spectra of M06 and M09 spent catalysts. Notwithstanding, the presence of segregated MgFe2O4 in the spent catalysts is corroborated because the signal of Fe3+ in A sites of MgFe2O4 is detected (green interaction in Fig. 2a). Therefore, during the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation with steam the nature of the MgFe2O4 is preserved. These results are in line with those from X-ray diffraction. 3.3 Specific surface area measurements and scanning electron microscopy The specific surface areas (Sg) of the catalysts are shown in Table 3. The values slightly decreased with magnesium addition up to Mg/Fe (molar) = 0.03. Although the crystallite size of hematite decreased by magnesium addition, as compared to hematite (Table 1), all phases aggregated themselves forming bigger particles ( Fig. 3) and then decreasing the specific surface area. It largely decreased for M06 sample because of the agglomeration of bigger crystals of hematite and magnesium ferrite. For M09 samples, the size of hematite crystals decreased, as compared to hematite, but the sizes of MgO and MgFe3O4 particles increased resulting in an aggregate as big as hematite. M01, M03 and M09 samples have hematite crystals smaller than pure hematite, which suggests that the other phases (magnesium compounds) keep the crystallites apart, avoiding sintering. The action of metal oxides as iron oxide spacers, leading to the formation of solids with smaller particles, has also been observed by other authors [42,43]. Topsøe, Dumesic and Boudart [43] for instance, have noted an increase in the specific surface area of iron oxide catalysts containing alumina. In addition, Costa, Marchetti and Rangel [44] have observed that thorium and copper increase the specific surface area of iron-based catalysts. The presence of magnesium compounds in the catalysts was demonstrated by X-ray diffraction except for M01 sample. For the M06 sample, magnesium oxide was not identified either. During ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, the specific surface area of iron oxide decreased, a fact that is related to the change of hematite to magnetite [44] and to the transformation of magnesium oxide to magnesium ferrite. The crystal sizes of magnetite slightly changed with magnesium content, but no regular tendency was noted. On the other hand, the crystal sizes of magnesium ferrite increased with magnesium amount. 3.4 Temperature-programmed reduction For pure hematite (F sample), two peaks were noted in the TPR curve ( Fig. 4), related to the reduction of Fe3+ in hematite to form the Fe2+ in magnetite (Fe3O4) and to the reduction of Fe2+ species to form metallic iron [44]. The first peak is detected at low temperature (300–400 ºC) while the second one occurs at high temperature (400–900 ºC) (Table S6). The second peak has a shoulder, which can be associated with the reduction of the surface followed by the reduction of the bulk, in agreement with previous results [44]. The growth and nucleation mechanism are used to reasonably describe the associated phenomenon of reducing hematite to magnetite [45]. According to this mechanism, the reducing gas reacts on the oxide surface, after a period of induction, causing the loss of oxygen from the surface and leading to the nucleation of the magnetite phase. This phase is porous, allowing the growth of the nucleated phase by continuous exposure of the non-reduced surface of the oxide to the reducing gas [46]. Therefore, the reduction is largely affected by the diffusion of the gas into the particle, causing the peaks to unfold in TPR curves. Wustite (FeO) is thermodynamically metastable and can hardly be detected during the reduction of hematite to metallic iron [47]. The curves for magnesium-doped samples (Fig. 4) depend on the magnesium content in the solids. Tables 4 and 5 show the temperatures at which each event begins, and the hydrogen amount consumed in each step, respectively. Magnesium shifts the temperature of the first peak to lower values, as compared to pure hematite, indicating that it facilitates the reduction of hematite to magnetite. For M01 and M03 samples, the temperature decreased, this being related to the small size of hematite particles due to magnesium. On the other hand, the reduction temperature increased for M06 and M09 samples, indicating that Fe3+ species are more easily reduced in hematite than in magnesium ferrite lattice. The high-temperature peak begins at 445 °C for pure hematite and is shifted to different temperatures depending on the magnesium content. As a whole, the temperature decreased because of magnesium, but no regular tendency was noted for increasing magnesium. M06 sample showed the highest reduction temperature, indicating that it is the catalyst most resistant to over reduction to metallic iron. Magnesium largely decreased the amount of reduced species (Fe3+ to Fe2+), as shown by hydrogen consumed by the catalysts, during the TPR experiments (Table 5). It can be seen that the hydrogen consumption of pure iron oxide was higher than the theoretical (26.862 mmol g−1), this being assigned to reducible impurities in the solids, such as nitrate ions, detected by infrared spectra (not shown). On the other hand, the experimental hydrogen consumption values of magnesium-doped iron samples were lower than the theoretical value indicating that magnesium makes the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ (2.98 mmol g−1) and Fe2+ to metallic iron (23.88 mmol g−1) more difficult. The degree of reduction in each step, as well as in the global process changed with the magnesium amount, being the M01 sample the most reducible. However, no simple relationship between these variables was found, which can be associated with the different phases, as well as their quantity, formed in each case. As shown in Fig. 4, magnesium oxide does not reduce under the conditions of the experiment. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and elemental analysis For all fresh catalysts, the spectra were similar to that of hematite, as illustrated in Figure S2. Table S6 shows the values of binding energy for all catalysts. The Fe3+ species were detected by a peak at around 710.9 eV, and a satellite structure located at the high binding energy side (716.6 eV), which is typical of hematite [48], in agreement with the results from X-ray diffraction and Mössbauer spectroscopy. The highest binding energy values, at around 717.1 eV are also characteristic of the Fe3+ species [48]. The binding energy of the Fe 2p3/2 level (710.9 eV) is characteristic of Fe3+ ions in octahedral sites of hematite [49]. The Mg 1 s core-level spectrum for M03 sample is shown in Figure S3. The binding energy (1303.9 eV) observed is compatible with magnesium oxide [48]. For the magnesium-richest samples, lower values were noted (around 1303.3 eV), due to the stabilization of cations in the magnesium ferrite environment [50]. Therefore, for M01 and M03 samples magnesium oxide was detected on the surface while magnesium ferrite was found on the surface of M06 and M09 samples. The binding energies of the O1s level indicate the presence of O2- ions in different chemical environments (Figure S4 and Table S6). The binding energies in the range of 529.3–529.9 ± 0.1 eV correspond to the O2- ions in an octahedral position characteristic of hematite. The energy values from 531.1 to 531.9 eV can be attributed to the hydroxyl groups on the surface, while that at 530.9 eV is characteristic of oxygen species on the surface [49]. The chemical composition of the catalyst surface obtained by XPS ( Table 6) shows that the magnesium content (and then Mg/Fe molar ratio) on the surface increases with the amount of this dopant in the solids, indicating the tendency of magnesium to deposit on the surface. For all samples, the Mg/Fe molar ratio is lower than the unity, indicating that the surface is rich in iron. From these results, one can conclude that for all samples the surface is made of magnesium compounds particles co-existing with hematite particles. Table S7 displays the results of the elemental analysis. We can note that the Mg/Fe molar ratios were close to the expected one, except for the M09 sample which shows a lower value. It means that some magnesium was lost during preparation. The comparison of these values with surface composition leads to the conclusion that hematite surface is richer in magnesium than the bulk and then the smaller particles magnesium compounds preferentially deposit on hematite surface or as particles isolated keeping hematite particles apart. 3.6 Catalytic activity The magnesium-containing samples exhibited higher activities than hematite, as shown in ( Fig. 5). Except for pure hematite, all catalysts convert more ethylbenzene than a commercial catalyst (10%) in the beginning of the reaction. Magnesium compounds largely improve the activity of iron oxides, leading to higher conversions in the beginning of reaction, which are close to each other. This common effect can be associated with the size of hematite particles, the amount of magnesium on the surface and with the density of structural defects, quantified as microstrain (σ) of each phase, shown in Table 1. It is well-known that the presence of defects in the solids increases the activity of the catalysts because they generate sites with increased energy and then more reactive. These effects are all caused by magnesium and their intensity depends on the catalyst composition. In the beginning of reaction, the ethylbenzene conversions over M01 and M03 samples are close due to the same size of hematite particles. M03 sample has the value of microstrain higher than M01 and should be more active but its surface is richer in magnesium and then some active sites may be covered by magnesium phases. M06 and M09 samples leads to similar conversions, but lower than the other magnesium-doped catalysts. This can be related to the higher amounts of magnesium on the surface, as shown by XPS (Table 6), which may cover some active sites. They have similar microstrain values but M06 has bigger hematite crystals and smaller crystals of magnesium ferrite than M09, resulting in similar activities( Table 7). During ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, the conversion changes indicating transformations in the catalysts on stream, mainly related to the phase change from hematite to magnetite. As reported previously [51], during reaction, an ethylbenzene molecule is adsorbed on both oxygen and on iron ions and then two hydrogen atoms are abstracted. Simultaneously, two electrons from ethyl groups go on the catalyst surface and the ethylene group is formed. This state represents the deactivated catalyst which is regenerated in situ by steam from the feed to produce Fe3+ ions. Therefore, the phase in operando is expected to be a mixture of Fe3+ and Fe2+ ions, such as magnetite. M01 and M03 samples show similar behaviors and lead to conversions close to each other during time reaction. Both catalysts slowly deactivate with time, this being related to the increase of crystals of iron oxide during the change from hematite to magnetite, since the microstrain values slightly change from 0.34 to 0.32 (M01) and from 0.5 to 0.46 (M03). M06 sample also deactivates with time reaction, achieving values between M03 and pure hematite. In this case, the crystal size of hematite decreases during the phase change (Table 1) and then it would be expected an increase in the conversion. In addition, more magnesium ferrite is produced during reaction, which is also active in the reaction [52]. However, the microstrain values decreased during reaction (0.54 for fresh and 0.46 for spent catalysts), which may decrease the reactivity during reaction. On the other hand, M09 sample slightly deactivates in the first 180 min of reaction. This leads to the increase of hematite crystals and to a decrease of the microstrain factor of hematite (0.76) as compared to magnetite (0.47). In spite of this fact, it remains stable over reaction time, probable because of the higher amount of magnesium ferrite as compared to M06 sample. As the surface of the catalysts is richer in iron than in magnesium compounds, the activity per area (a/Sg) should adequately represent the activity of the catalytic sites (intrinsic activity) for the samples. After 6 h on stream (Table 4), magnesium increases the intrinsic activity, which can be related to the decrease of crystal sizes and to the increase of defects in iron oxides, by the stresses generated by other phases. All magnesium-containing catalysts were more selective to styrene when compared to pure hematite. Except for M06 sample, all containing-magnesium catalysts achieved around 100% of selectivity, producing neither benzene nor toluene, due to the basic sites of magnesium oxide in the catalysts, in accordance with previous works [4,6,15,22]. The M06 sample was the least selective catalyst, a fact that can be related to the absence of magnesium oxide, able to inhibits cracking (Eq. 2) and hydrogenolysis (Eq. 3) reactions to produce benzene and toluene, respectively, besides coke. The styrene yields for magnesium-containing catalysts (Table 4) were higher than for hematite. The solid with the highest magnesium content (M09 sample) produced the highest amount of styrene and therefore is the most promising catalyst for industrial applications. It can avoid the recycling of ethylbenzene and separation operations, leading to a decrease in operating costs, besides not being toxic. 4 Conclusions Catalysts prepared by simultaneous hydrolysis of iron nitrate and magnesium nitrate with ammonium hydroxide, at room temperature, followed by heating at 600 ºC have proven to be promising to selectively produce styrene from dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene with steam. Different amounts of magnesium (Mg= 0.1; 0.3; 0.6 and 0.9) generate catalysts with different properties made off hematite, magnesium oxide and magnesium ferrite, the amount depending on the solid composition. During ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, hematite changes to magnetite and all magnesium oxide changes to magnesium ferrite. There is no simple relationship between the amount of magnesium and the activity, selectivity and stability of the catalysts. The magnesium-containing phases affect the size of hematite crystals, the amount of defects in solids, and the availability of active sites on the surface as well as the catalyst reducibility. Depending on magnesium amount these properties combine to each other generating catalysts with different activity, selectivity and stability. The catalyst with Mg/Fe= 0.09 was the most active, highly selective to styrene (100%) and lead to the highest yield (26%). This catalyst is promising for industrial applications, with the advantage of being nontoxic. Its high selectivity could minimize recycling ethylbenzene and separation operations, leading to a reduction in operating costs. The role of magnesium compounds is mainly related to the intrinsic activity rather textural properties. They can thus replace potassium oxide in commercial hematite catalysts but not chromium compounds since they have no effect on the textural properties of the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Styrene is an important building block of the plastics industry being produced by ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. The commercial catalysts have the disadvantages of deactivation by potassium loss and coke deposition, and chromium toxicity. To overcome these drawbacks, a new catalyst was developed by investigating the effect of magnesium on the catalytic properties of hematite in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. Hematite was detected for all fresh catalysts and magnetite for the spent ones. Magnesium was found as magnesium ferrite and magnesium oxide, depending on the magnesium amount. Magnesium compounds affect the crystal sizes, the amount of defects and the reducibility of iron oxides, the predominance of each one depending on the composition of the solids. These effects caused important differences in activity, selectivity and stability of the catalysts. The catalyst with Mg/Fe = 0.09, consisting of aggregates of hematite, MgO and magnesium ferrite, showed the highest yield, being the most promising for commercial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene over magnesium-doped hematite catalysts
